sub_topic: Quantification of the amount of a substance in a sample using gravimetric analysis
message_1: What is the mass percentage of copper (Cu) in a sample of pure copper chloride (CuCl2) obtained from gravimetric analysis if 2.57 g of copper chloride were heated to drive off all the HCl and water vapor and only 1.97 g of pure copper remained?
message_2:
To find the mass percentage of copper (Cu) in a sample of pure copper chloride (CuCl2), we can use the following formula:

Mass percentage of Cu = (mass of Cu / mass of CuCl2) × 100

Given that 2.57 g of copper chloride were heated and 1.97 g of pure copper remained, we can plug these values into the formula:

Mass percentage of Cu = (1.97 g / 2.57 g) × 100

Mass percentage of Cu ≈ 0.7665 × 100

Mass percentage of Cu ≈ 76.65%

Therefore, the mass percentage of copper (Cu) in the sample of pure copper chloride (CuCl2) is approximately 76.65%.
